titlestmt.subtitle: An inventory of Charles L. McCollough at DC Public Library
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Ryan P. Semmes.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-02-20 10:50:47 -0500.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Charles Leon McCollough was born in Washington, DC on March 12, 1941 to his parents Bishop Walter McCollough and Clara B. McCollough. He graduated from Cardozo High School where he lettered in track. He then joined his father as a Minister at his father's church, the United House of Prayer for All People. His father, "Sweet Daddy" McCollough was the leader of a congregation that included millions of members around the country. Ordained in 1967, Charles was a pastor at the United House of Prayer from 1975 to 1992.

In 1991, Walter "Sweet Daddy" McCollough died. It was assumed that Charles would take over as Bishop of the House of Prayer. However, he lost the election for Bishop to S. C. Madison amid cries of a rigged election. He filed a lawsuit challenging the results, but it was dismissed as an ecclesiastical matter that the court would stay out of. Charles was subsequently stripped of his position as pastor in the United House of Prayer. Charles continued to allege other abuses by Bishop Madison, including the swindling of property from Charles' late father and the refusal of the church to allow Clara to be interred in her husband's mausoleum at Fort Lincoln Cemetery.

Charles, his wife Marjorie Colee (nee. July 25, 1943), his con Charles, jr. (nee. October 4, 1970), and daughter Marjorie Clarissa McCollough-Jackson (nee February 25, 1966) established the Believers in Christ Ministries and conducted efforts on behalf of the poor in Washington, DC, including Thanksgiving Baskets, toys at Christmas, tutoring programs, and anti-drugs programs.
Charles died on June 22, 1996 at the age of 55, of a heart attack, which he suffered after eulogizing his late nephew David Robinson.
(Information taken from Obituary, Washington Post, June 28, 1996, C4.)

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The collection was donated to the DC Community Archives by Charles L. McCollough's widow, Marjorie C. McCollough in 1997.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of records that document the Ministry and life of Charles L. McCollough, Pastor of the United House of Prayer. Documents include: clippings, correspondence, speeches, sermons, meeting minutes and agendas, youth program information, certificates and awards, and photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence in this series consists of letters to C. L. McCollough, letters to members of his family and letters from members of his family.

did.unittitle: Walter E. Fauntroy - Clergy Advisory Committee
Receipt for Telegram to MLK Jr. Family after Assassination

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of clippings, an itinerary, and memorabilia from Walter McCollough and Family's trip to the Holy Land in 1967. It includes postcards and photographs.

did.unittitle: Bishop Walter's Trip to Holy Land
Christmas Card from the Holy Land

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains full sermons and sermon notes used by C. L. McCollough. The sermons are arranged alphabetically by their title or subject.

did.unittitle: A Faith By Which to Die

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, memorabilia, meeting minutes, and other materials that show C. L. McCollough's work with both the United House of Prayer and Believers in Christ Ministries.

did.unittitle: Clergy and Church Monitors District 6 and 7
Coalition of Concerned Clergy and Citizens of Ward 7
Little Angel's and Youth Enrichment Program
Reinstatement of Pastor C. L. McCollough

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V contains programs from events that honored the McColloughs, were attended by the McColloughs, or were organized by their organizations.

did.unittitle: Thelonious Monk International Jazz Piano Competition

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The United House of Prayer, as well as, the City Council of Washington, DC and the National Organization of Free Masons gave the awards and Certificates in this series to C. L. McCollough or his organization.

did.unittitle: Coalition of Concerned Citizenry in the Community
United House of Prayer Achievement Certificates

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Oversize Outreach and Awards materials are found in this series. They include photographs and certificates.
